coredata.dc:description: AbstractA synthetic aperture radar ERS-1 scene, used to complement a Landsat TM scene, allows better understanding of the structure of the active Ovacik fault, southwest of Erzincan (Turkey). The radar image shows that the Ovacik fault is interrupted at its crossing point with the Kemaliye fault. Recent compressive displacements have reactivated the Kemaliye fault, while a pull-apart basin has been generated along the Ovacik fault. Estimates of offsets of major rivers and analysis of the complex fault geometry given an estimated left-lateral strike slip displacement of 12.5â20 km along the Ovacik fault for the last 13 Ma, which is similar to the rate of movement along the East Anatolian fault located in the east and forming the boundary of the Turkish plate.

Chorowicz,* P. Luxey,*J. P. Rudant,* N. Lyberis,* T. Yiiriir,* and N. Giindo~du* A synthetic aperture radar ERS-1 scene, used to comple- ment a Landsat TM scene, allows better understanding of the structure of the active Ovacik fault, southwest of Erzincan (Furkey). The radar image shows that the Ovacik fault is interrupted at its crossing point with the Kemaliye fault. Recent compressive displacements have reactivated the Kemaliye fault, while a pull-apart basin has been generated along the Ovacik fault. Estimates of offsets of major rivers and analysis of the complex fault geometry give an estimated left-lateral strike slip displacement of 12.5-20 km along the Ovacik fault for the last 13 Ma, which is similar to the rate of movement along the East Anatolian fault located in the east and forming the bound- ary of the Turkish plate. INTRODUCTION A synthetic aperture radar (SAR) scene acquired by the European Research Satellite number one (ERS-1) provides a view (Fig. 1) somewhat different from the view offered by a former Landsat TM scene (Fig. 2) of a tectonically active (Arpat and Saroglu, 1975) area southwest of Erzincan (Turkey). ENVIRON. 52:66-70 (1995) lsevier Science Inc., 1995 655 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10010 feature in this area is the Ovacik fault, an active sinistral strike-slip fault (Perin~ek et al., 1987) related to the westward motion of the eastern Turkish (Anatolian) plate with respect to Eurasia an Arabia (Barka and Giilen, 1989), along the North Anatolian and the East Anatolian faults (McKenzie, 1972) (Fig. 3). Interpreta- tion of these complementary images allows an estimate of the motion along the Ovacik fault. ANALYSIS OF THE RADAR IMAGE The radar image (Fig. 1) was acquired on 20 September 1991. Illumination is from the east. The slopes at right angle to the radar beam appear bright and narrower than they really are because they subparallel the radar wave surface and give an oversaturated backscattered echo. The northeastern segment of the Ovacik fault is underlined by a rectilinear and narrow valley (Figs. la and 4). It extends along strike southwestward into a scarp overlooking the rhomb shaped Ovacik pull-apart basin (Figs. lb and 4), which is essentially covered by alluvial fans and late Quaternary moraine (Arpat and Saroglu, 1975) issued from the Munzur mountain. The fault subvertically cuts the moraines, creating small scarps visible on the radar image (Fig. lc) and confirming recent activity. The major new observation brought by the radar image is that the Ovacik fault is not continuous (Perin~ek et al., 1987) but rather interrupted to the south by a ridge trending at high angle to the fault strike (Fig. ld). The ridge is bounded to the south by the east-striking Kemaliye fault (Figs. le and 4). To the west, the Kemaliye fault is not visible on the image, 0034-4257 / 95 / $9.50 SSDI 0034-4257(95)00014-R Slip-Motion Estimation with ERS-1 Imagery 67 39oF 38o30' E 39o30'N 39 38o30,E 39 ~ 39o30'N $39ON Figure 1. SAR ERS-1 image over southern Erzincan region (Turkey), acquired on 20 September 1991, covering a 100 x 100 km area. Illumination is from the east: a-j) See explanation in the text. because it is precisely parallel to the direction of illumi- nation. More to the south, the Ovacik fault reappears and is characterized by a rectilinear but relatively shal- low dry valley (Figs. If and 4). The Euphrates, Murat, and Kozluk Rivers cross this valley and are left-laterally shifted (Figs. lg, h, and i). Linear features seem to be smaller associated faults. ANALYSIS OF THE LANDSAT TM IMAGE The Landsat Thematic Mapper scene belongs to the path and row 173-33 and was acquired on 24 September 1987 (Fig. 2). One inconvenience of visible-near-infra- red data, including Landsat TM imagery, is that when the topography is not outlined by sun shade, the geomor- phology is difficult to interpret. Thus, the southern segment of the Ovacik fault is hardly visible on the Landsat TM image. The northeastern segment of the Ovacik fault and the Ovacik basin are here again well imaged (Figs. 2a and b). Rivers flowing from the Munzur Mountain into the Ovacik basin are left-laterally shifted (Figs. 2c, d, and e), indicating recent activity. As they are issued from the glaciers, their ages probably postdate the latest warming event, that is, 10,000 years :t 2,000. However, the amount of shift is difficult to estimate on the images and seems related to the age of the rivers, that is the river having the largest valley and alluvial fan shows the largest offset. The ridge south of the Ovacik basin is also visible but a small valley, underlined by sun shade (Fig. 2i), suggests that the Ovacik fault crosscuts the ridge. However, the radar image clearly shows (Fig. l j) that this valley is not rectilinear and consequently cannot be considered superimposed to a subvertical fault: The Ovacik fault is effectively inter- rupted. The Kemaliye fault (Perin~ek et al., 1987; Mi- chard et al., 1984) is clearly outlined to the west of the ridge (Fig. 2g). The corresponding scarp is quite straight, attesting a rather steep dip of the fault plane. 68 Chorowicz et al. 39 .39o30'N 39030, E 39 39OE 3810'E 3~OE Figure 2. Partial view of the Landsat TM image covering the area of Erzincan, acquired on 24 September 1987. This picture is a black and white reproduction of the color composite image, made from merge of Bands TM 2, 3, and 4. The white areas are covered with snow: a-g) See explanation in text. INTERPRETATION Active faults in the area may not be older than 13 Ma because the westward motion of the Turkish plate (Perin~ek et al., 1987) has started at that time (Dewey and Seng6r, 1979; Seng6r, 1979). The Kemaliye fault is compressive (Michard et al., 1984), and the scarps observed on the Landsat TM image are poorly eroded, indicating recent activity. Re- cent motion of the Ovacik fault has reactivated an an- cient Kemaliye fault. This reactivation is evidenced by the location of the Kemaliye fault at the boundary be- tween the Kemaliye melange to the north and the Eocene flysch to the south. Their being in contact indicates a considerable throw predating the late Cretaceous thrust of the Munzur mountain (Michard et al., 1984). The recent movement of this fault, evidenced at its Western end (Fig. 4), displaces slightly the nappe contact. A major observation brought by the radar image is the interruption of the Ovacik fault by the ridge related to the Kemaliye fault zone and its reappearance to the south. The following model may explain this structure: The ancient Kemaliye fault affecting the autochthonous series has refracted the Ovacik fault during its propaga- tion (Fig. 5A); the left-lateral motion along the Ovacik fault opened a pull-apart basin (Fig. 5B) while compres- sive reactivation of the Kemaliye fault formed the ridge. The length of the present day Ovacik pull-apart, as it appears on the images, is caused mainly by the basin opening and to a lesser extent by gravitational collapse (Fig. 5C). The 20 km NE-SW length of the pull-apart basin will thus be an upper boundary of the real offset along the Ovacik fault. The shortening effect can be estimated in a simple manner: peneplana- tion following late-Cretaceous tectonic events (Dewey and Seng6r, 1979; Seng6r, 1979) implies that the present day topography is mostly the result of recent deforma- tions (Fig. 5D). The present day topography represents uplifting and folding due to motion along the Kemaliye fault. We estimate graphically L2 to a minimum of 1.5 km. The total mini- mum shortening across the Kemaliye fault is 3.5 km (thick arrow on Fig. 5D). Offset along the southwestern seg- ment of the Ovacik fault is given by the left-lateral shift on the Euphrates River (Fig. 4) yielding 9 km. The total minimum offset along the Ovacik fault is thus 12.5 km. The maximum offset is the length of the Ovacik pull- apart basin, that is, 20 km. Offset along the Ovacik fault may therefore be estimated between 12.5 km and 20 km. CONCLUSIONS The faults being regarded as 13 Ma old, the mean slip rate calculated on the Ovacik fault would be of the order of 1 mm yr- t. This result is similar to the estimated ca 1.1 mm yr-1 slip rate since middle-late Miocene along the East Anatolian fault lying parallelly more to the east (Dewey and Seng6r, 1979; Seng6r, 1979). Consequently, the rate of strike-slip deformation of the Ovacik fault located inside the Turkish plate is very similar to the rate of motion along the East Anatolian border fault, evidencing important internal deformation of the plate.
